results.title: Introduction to optics
results.creator_credit: Norton Bloom and Educational Services Incorporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Elbert P. Little discusses the approximation that light travels in a straight line and demonstrates how its direction is changed by diffraction, scattering, refraction and reflection. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:

results.title: The Interference of photons
results.creator_credit: Educational Services Incorporated and Physical Sciences Study Committee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Presents an experiment at MIT in which light exhibits both particle and wave characteristics. Characteristic interference pattern is pointed out by many individual photons hitting at places consistent with the interference pattern.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Educational Services Incorporated and Physical Sciences Study Committee

results.title: Inertial mass
results.creator_credit: Norton Bloom, Stephen White and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Edward M. Purcell demonstrates that acceleration is inversely proportional to mass with force constant and that different objects may have the same inertial mass. Compares inertial and gravitational mass and shows how they are proportional. A continuation of the film “Inertia”.

results.title: Inertia
results.creator_credit: Educational Services and Physical Sciences Study Committee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Edward M. Purcell demonstrates Galileo’s principle of inertia in experiments with a body moving horizontally with minimal friction and using low friction dry-ice pucks and multiple flash photography showing acceleration is proportional to force when mass is constant. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Educational Services and Physical Sciences Study Committee

results.title: Frames of reference
results.creator_credit: Richard Leacock, Kevin Smith, Stephen White and Educational Services Incorporated Film Division
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Demonstrates the changes in observed motion of a freely falling body viewed from differently moving frames of reference. Donald Ivey and Patterson Hume discuss relative motion, accelerated and inertial frames of reference, and show the inadequacy of Newtonian physics, calling for calculation of fictitious forces to describe relative motions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Leacock, Kevin Smith, Stephen White and Educational Services Incorporated Film Division
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.

Donald Ivey and Patterson Hume discuss relative motion, accelerated and inertial frames of reference, and show the inadequacy of Newtonian physics, calling for calculation of fictitious forces to describe relative motions.

results.title: Forces
results.creator_credit: Norton Bloom, Stephen White, Educational Services and Physical Sciences Study Committee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Introduces the principles of mechanics by showing the Cavendish experiment which illustrates the gravitational forces between small objects. Also compares gravitational force with magnetic force. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norton Bloom, Stephen White, Educational Services and Physical Sciences Study Committee

results.title: Energy and work
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Part of the “Physical science study committee series” presents experimental evidence that the work done on a body, measured as the area under the force-distance curve, is a measure of the transfer of kinetic energy to the body calculated from its mass and velocity. Dorothy Montgomery demonstrates the relationships using mechanical devices.
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Part of the “Physical science study committee series” presents experimental evidence that the work done on a body, measured as the area under the force-distance curve, is a measure of the transfer of kinetic energy to the body calculated from its mass and velocity. Dorothy Montgomery demonstrates the relationships using mechanical devices.

results.title: Electric Fields
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Discusses an electric field as a mathematical aid and as a physical entity. Experiments demonstrate the vector addition of fields, the shielding effect by closed metallic surfaces and the electric force which drives an electric current in a conductor.
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Discusses an electric field as a mathematical aid and as a physical entity. Experiments demonstrate the vector addition of fields, the shielding effect by closed metallic surfaces and the electric force which drives an electric current in a conductor.

results.title: Elastic collisions and stored energy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Demonstrates the concept of stored energy. Uses the example of collisions between two dry-ice pucks. Cylindrical magnets are mounted on the pucks, producing a repelling force, and the kinetic energy of the pucks is measured. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Demonstrates the concept of stored energy. Uses the example of collisions between two dry-ice pucks. Cylindrical magnets are mounted on the pucks, producing a repelling force, and the kinetic energy of the pucks is measured. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Coulomb's law
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Demonstrates the inverse square relationship between electric force and distance and shows that electric force is directly proportional to charge.
